question: DAOs must fully comply with the financial regulatory laws of their respective countries, even if it requires sacrificing anonymity.
It is acceptable to temporarily authorize a core developer team to urgently repair the protocol in the event of a hack.
Requiring governance token holders to complete KYC verification is a necessary cost to secure partnerships with mainstream financial institutions.
Users should manage their own private keys (even if they may lose them) rather than adopt 'centralized' solutions like social recovery wallets.
To attract billions of users, protocols should support direct fiat purchases of tokens (e.g., credit card gateways), even if it relies on centralized custodians.
Layer 2 scaling solutions should prioritize the most secure technology (e.g., ZK-Rollup), even if ordinary users struggle to understand the principles behind them.
DAO treasuries should prioritize token buybacks and burns to boost token prices rather than funding long-term ecosystem development.
Even if it may result in losses, funding non-profit social impact projects like anti-censorship communication tools is essential.
High-APY liquidity mining is the best way to attract users, even if it leads to token inflation.
All on-chain transactions should hide sender/receiver addresses by default, visible only to participants.
Regulators have the right to require DeFi protocols to disclose the source of funds for transactions exceeding $100,000.
Privacy coins (e.g., Monero, Zcash) are indispensable infrastructure for the Web3 ecosystem.
Complex technical decisions (e.g., consensus algorithm upgrades) should be delegated to core developer teams rather than community voting.
Whales holding over 100,000 tokens should have additional voting weight, as they are more invested in the protocol's long-term success.
All governance proposals must undergo full community voting, even if it slows decision-making.
Protocols should encourage rapid deployment of unaudited innovative DeFi projects, even with potential vulnerabilities.
It is better to halt all new feature development for a year to ensure absolute security and stability of existing systems.
Protocol forks are a sign of a healthy ecosystem, even if they may fragment community cohesion.
The future of Web3 depends on balancing idealism with practical feasibility.
True decentralization means accepting inefficiency, high costs, and high risks.
